qas.question: Where did Rome receive half of their army from?
How many calvary did Rome's Italian allies use?
How many soldiers were available to Rome at the start of the Second Punic War?
What did Rome's Italian allies call their battle formation?
What allowed Rome to source some of their military from other nearby areas?

answers.text: military confederation with the other peoples

context: Rome's <a4_0>military confederation with the other peoples<a4_0/> of the Italian peninsula meant that half of Rome's army was provided by <a0_0>the Socii<a0_0/>, such as the Etruscans, Umbrians, Apulians, Campanians, Samnites, Lucani, Bruttii, and the various southern Greek cities. Polybius states that Rome could draw on <a2_0>770,000 men<a2_0/> at the beginning of the Second Punic War, of which 700,000 were infantry and 70,000 met the requirements for cavalry. Rome's Italian allies would be organized in <a3_0>alae<a3_0/>, or wings, roughly equal in manpower to the Roman legions, though with <a1_0>900 cavalry<a1_0/> instead of 300.
